FOR Statements

[not implemented]
FOR-statement loops should be shown in the diagram either when there are annotated actions inside or when we have 'highlighted/underlined' the FOR-statement with the //$ notation. We can add user-defined conditions before or after the FOR-statement. We can also quote the calls to functions/methods in the loop-condition.

annotation

a) comments after: 

      for(Loop = 0; Loop < Parameter; Loop ++)    //$ 
      //$ [loop condition] 
      {
      //$ action 1
      code
      }

a) comments before: 

      //$ [loop condition] 
      for(Loop = 0; Loop < Parameter; Loop ++) {   //$ 
      //$ action 1
      code
      }

//$: forces displaying in the diagram the calls to functions/methods inside the conditionStatement
//$ [condition A]: specifies the condition; the square brackets [ ] are required syntax

representation in the diagram


loop condition = ‘over individual terms’, ‘for all elements of the vector V’, ...


  • When there is (at least) an annotated action in the loop, the diagram will be drawn at the corresponding zoom level. The zoom level for the loop will correspond to the greater zoom level of all actions.
  • The comment specifying the loop condition is optional. It will also drive the drawing of the diagram, in a secondary basis.
  • The conditions that are not specified will be taken from the code.

calls to functions/methods in the conditionStatements
When the loop-condition involves calls to a method/function, these calls will be shown as actionable hyperlinks, provided that there exists the relevant diagram(s):
  • conditionStatement read directly from the code: always shown. Example:
  • user-defined condition: shown only if the //$ option is present. Example:
